awd_titl_txt: SRS-RN Planning Grant: Integrated and Convergent Sea Level Adaptation for Urban and Rural Systems in the Gulf of Mexico Coastal Regions
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed planning grant will address the challenge of responding to sea level rise (SLR) in linked urban-rural systems located along the Gulf of Mexico Coastal Region (GCR). Urban and rural areas in the GCR are part of a geographical continuum composed of interdependent nodes connected by synergistic linkages, wherein the urban areas depend on the rural areas for natural resources and the rural areas depend on the urban areas for services. SLR threatens the links that bind urban and rural communities together in the GCR. Compared with much of the world, the rate of SLR is quite high across much of the GCR and its landscape is a relatively low-lying coastal plain. Moreover, disadvantaged minority groups compose a large fraction of both the urban and rural population in this region, yielding a high degree of social vulnerability. The typical SLR response strategies in the GCR are often practiced differentially across urban versus rural areas. The aim of this planning grant is to build a consolidated SLR adaptation strategy that enables urban and rural communities to collaboratively sustain the natural and physical infrastructure that links them together. 

The proposed approach will be driven by convergent research of experts and by co-production of knowledge and ideas from stakeholder engagement. The project team will bring together an inclusive and diverse group of researchers, community leaders, and policy makers who do not normally interact. This group will create convergent research outputs and foster stakeholder relationships to build a collaborative Track 1 Sustainable Regional Systems Research Networks (SRS-RN) proposal. The execution of this effort will follow a trajectory with three phases: (1) an on-line high-performance charrette will be used to coordinate partnering researchers and stakeholders, and assemble the foundations of the network, (2) an in-person charrette will be used to co-produce research priorities and hypotheses for the proposed SRS-RN, (3) a concentered expert workshop will integrate these efforts and synthesize the output products. This planning grant is a unique opportunity to (a) coalesce interdisciplinary teams, focus on the commonalities at the urban-rural linkages, (b) identify priorities, needs, and incentives of diverse stakeholders, (c) build knowledge and trust across these communities, and (d) formulate the research objectives, hypotheses, and methods for an innovative research network structure. Network activities will focus on the inclusion of minority constituencies, groups, and institutions that have been historically excluded from the SLR response conversation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This planning project tackled the challenge of rising sea levels in the Gulf of Mexico Coastal Region (GCR). It explored new research topics and was a nexus for building capacity among researchers and communities affected by sea level rise, leading towards several convergent outcomes. Aligning with the 2012 RESTORE Act, we defined the US portion of the GCR as the 700,000 square km coastal portions of the states of Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Texas, and all of Florida. While an increasing number of researchers and practitioners have focused on developing adaptation strategies, they have often been narrow in scope or focused on a particular problem or risk. Typically, the common-denominator solution has been to install site-specific defenses. However, the highly variable spatial and temporal nature of sea-level rise (SLR) requires comprehensive, collaborative, and robust planning across a region to successfully defend the territory and coordinate various interests with a consolidated front. This project took a critical step towards bridging this gap and creating effective collaboration models and holistic solutions for SLR adaptation. It achieved this step by employing a systems science approach and bringing together a diverse group of researchers, experts, policy makers, and nonprofit organizations. 

Initiating with an in-person charrette alongside a climate change conference, we gathered a diverse group to formulate research questions and outline essential components. This event set the tone for collaborative planning, emphasizing the importance of converging perspectives. Expanding our reach, an online charrette allowed for further discussions on research thrusts, stakeholder engagement, and educational plans. Insights from this virtual collaboration laid the groundwork for subsequent planning and actions. Throughout our project, communication was a key pillar. Over forty meetings, spanning emails and video conferences, connected us with individuals from academia, NGOs, regional planners, local governments, and community outreach specialists. This extensive network provided a foundation for addressing the multifaceted challenges of SLR. The project's pinnacle unfolded in a workshop and charrette, bringing together a diverse group of individuals. Esteemed panelists and lightning talk speakers shared valuable insights, shaping the groundwork for a future full-scale proposal.

To disseminate knowledge and foster team development, we organized accessible seminars. The recorded sessions, shared online, served as valuable resources to enhance our collective understanding and readiness for the proposed full-scale initiative. To lay conceptual foundations for the future, we composed several scholarly papers reviewing resilience metrics and decision-making in the context of infrastructure adaptation. These publications contribute to a growing body of knowledge in our field. Additionally, a paper addressing quantified resilience metrics in the context of SLR, and infrastructure has been published. Beyond the events within our original project scope, our project team also actively participated in collaboration with other SRS projects. This collaboration extended to the development of a paper about defining and achieving convergence in the context of our shared goals, highlighting the expanding capacity within our team.

The efforts of the project team and the activities undertaken have resulted in the identification of key thrust areas essential for achieving convergence in research on SLR resilience. The first requirement is was to coordinate the priorities, needs, and incentives of stakeholder communities from the outset and to focus on commonalities at the urban-rural linkages. Another related component is to include minority constituencies, groups, and institutions that have historically been excluded from the conversation on SLR response. The third thrust is to co-design a multi-dimensional channel of communication among stakeholders and researchers, bridging urban and rural interests, as well as government and citizens. The next step is to integrate these efforts into synthetic research products and co-produce actionable solutions and plans from the bottom-up. Finally, it is important that such convergent research is tailored to educate scientists, engineers, policymakers, local governments, and community advocates about coordinated territory defense against SLR. In this planning project, our focus has been on building the capacity for fostering comprehensive and inclusive research on SLR resilience. The combined results from our collaborative efforts signify a strategic investment in knowledge, networks, and readiness, paving the way for a more resilient future in the face of rising sea levels.
